org.mellowtech.core.io

Class IntArrayFile

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mellowtech.core.io.IntArrayFile
  • Deprecated.

    @Deprecated
public class IntArrayFile
extends Object
    Simple disc-based integer array. This class effectivly is an array of ints that is stored on disc. Furthermore this is a dynamic array, meaning that it is always as large as the number of elements in it.
    Author:
    rickard.coster@asimus.se

    • Constructor Detail

      • IntArrayFile

        public IntArrayFile(String fileName,
                    boolean failSafe,
                    boolean deleteOldFile,
                    boolean direct)
             throws IOException
        Deprecated. 
        Creates a new disc based int array.
        Parameters:
        fileName - file name of this array
        failSafe - always write values to disc
        deleteOldFile - if false the old (if it exists) array will be used
        direct - use direct allocation for the buffer holding the array.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs
        See Also:
        ByteBuffer

        Close this array, i.e write all data to file

        IOException - if an error occurs

      • binarySearch

        public int binarySearch(int key)
        Deprecated. 
        (Follows the general contract in Arrays) Searches the array for the specified value using the binary search algorithm. The array must be sorted (as by the sort method, below) prior to making this call. If it is not sorted, the results are undefined. If the array contains multiple elements with the specified value, there is no guarantee which one will be found.
        Parameters:
        key - the value to be searched for.
        Returns:
        index of the search key, if it is contained in the array; otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1). The insertion point is defined as the point at which the key would be inserted into the list: the index of the first element greater than the key, or list.size(), if all elements in the list are less than the specified key. Note that this guarantees that the return value will be >= 0 if and only if the key is found.
        See Also:
        Arrays.sort(long[])

      • put

        public void put(int record,
                int value)
         throws IOException
        Deprecated. 
        Adds a record to this array. If the record was previously taken the array is shifted to the right to make room for the new record, i.e we want to insert 34 in record 1
        1 9 8 yields 1 34 9 8
        Parameters:
        record - the new record
        value - the valud for that record
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs
